text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: They, they uh, I don’t think they’ve worked out totally the scheme of what’s the best way to do it, every two months at most it’s been. Each center does it slightly different. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh but that’s, that’s about what they do. Uh I’m not really sure because they haven’t seen profound bone marrow effects. One of the problems with radioactive things is you can get- Patient: Sure. Um hum. Doctor: Injury to the bone marrow. My experience with them is that particularly with patients who’ve had, not had a lot of chemotherapy, so not a lot of things to injure the bone marrow, they don’t seem to really have a problem with bone marrow toxicity from this study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The only place they run into problems is if somebody comes with you know five-hundred things in the bowel, and we’re putting this radiation in cancer, in terms of next to the bone cells, those people mostly get bone marrow problems. But in regard to you, I would expect probably not from the bone marrow. Family Member: Can you get him in this? Doctor: Well the German thing is you know unfortunately you’d have to pay for it. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So it’s not a study.

text: Patient: So you’re… Family Member: She’s serious. Doctor: No I am, I’m serious. Patient: Wake up, wake up, five more? Doctor: Yeah, total over time, but let’s just do one at a time. Patient: Oh. Doctor: The key is you’re still – you know it’s still shrinking. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Until I get you – you could get five more, but if you beat me by getting your PSA to zero, then I’ll stop. Patient: Okay. Doctor: How’s that for a challenge? Family Member: So if it comes back today and it’s zero?

text: Patient: But I - you know from sitting in the car for an hour coming up here and that’s - Doctor: Yeah, and the cold right now - Patient: And the cold and sitting - Doctor: And the other thing is as you lose your hair, since we’re doing this right in the middle of winter, you have to protect your head. Family Member: Yeah. Yes. Doctor: Because that’s a sudden change that your body in this cold will really have a tough time getting used to. Yes. Family Member: I had a question about if it does cause nausea (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Does that last the full three weeks or does it taper off? Doctor: Oh no. Most – I would not expect you to have significant nausea at all. I am going to give you a prescription on you know Zofran in case you need it. But most people don’t need more than what we give them today, right. Okay, so it’s not expected. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Looking at the first scan we did when we first started. The scan we did after enzalutamide. So then we’re back at sort of like this. It sort of looks like we’re staying on. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So things are still growing at a slow to moderate pace, I’d say. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh so yeah I, I, I’m always concerned about that but I don’t think it’s reflective of making it grow more. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now we have seen folks you know stop the testosterone and PSA goes back down. Some of that elevation is related to, to stimulate production. Patient: Right. Doctor: So you know we’d like to see where, where we go with that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh in terms of once we reboot to be well again. The uh the problem we face is you know looking at the trials there are sort of two levels of looking at what’s available next.

text: Patient: Uh, is difficult because I wake up in the morning, and I can feel some pain, strain or whatever. Uh, it’s strange that when I go and I had the two blood transfusions, that I could be on that table for five hours, laying on my back, and I don’t have no problem. I don’t know what the correlation that is. I tried to lift the bed up, and, uh, the, uh, the foot part, and I guess I haven’t found the, uh, the right position yet for it, for me that, that works. Uh, the, uh, but for the most part, we’ve been, we’ve been working through it. Doctor: How many oxycodone are you taking now? Patient: Uh. Doctor: Looking at this list. Patient: Well, my son did that. You know? He’s military. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So he, but actually, the oxycodone are the ones with the numbers there? One or two at the beginning. Because that’s the way he did it. And when I do it, I just put down when I’m taking it. I don’t that, take it that often. I know that, uh, uh, when I got the prescription, they told me to stay in front of the, the pain, so, or else you’re going to have to start from scratch again to get back where you were at. But I was a little leery of taking, uh, uh, uh, drugs that often. Doctor: So it looks like some days you’re taking it twice, like August eighteenth? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then some days, like August twentieth, you didn’t take it at all? Patient: No. Doctor: And twenty-first, you didn’t take it at all, and then the twenty-second, which is today, you took one in the morning? Patient: Yes. And I took one when I got here, too. I didn’t write it down. I took one after I got here because I could feel in my thighs, so I did take one, uh, when we got to the, to, the facility today.

text: Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: I don’t know either. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They just said it was inadequate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we don’t have any results about are there gene studies that you could go on. Uhm, so the ARV7 positive means that you know your cancer is pretty smart and knows how to grow despite testosterone being low, despite being on drugs like the Zytiga or the Xtandi, and that really you know as I said last time, at some point we have to decide when your cancer is worse. I tend not to rely on PSA. Patient: Mm. Doctor: It really is are there new things about you that are going in the wrong direction and yet after radiation, it seems like things are in a better direction at least in the last month in terms of your pain. Patient: Oh yes, absolutely. Doctor: We’ve got a CAT scan that I don’t have access to, but sort of what does that show? And with you know new belly films you know to sort of say what’s going on in your liver, you know so Dr. G___ and I can talk about that, sort of when, what images we need, to say okay his PSA is higher and on scan we see more cancer. And you know some of what we’re really talking about is what do we do if we tell you that. Does that bring up questions? Patient: In other words where do we go from here? Doctor: What is your understanding or what Dr. G__ talked about. Patient: Nothing really new that I remember that he thought you know with the ARB7, is that it?

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
